attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a physical count of raw materials and finished product on 25th April 2025 to determine the effectiveness and adequacy of existing stock controls at the branch. (N/B: Roof repair was being done at the branch and production had been stopped from 23rd April and resumed on 24th April Night Shift)
  • The findings were listed and tabulated below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +20 pieces
    • The finished product had a variance of -37 pieces after adjusting for 180.5 loaves in deduction numbers 41084/82/83 and 49531 posted but rejected due to low bread balance but was reposted after stock & subsequent production.
    • All other raw materials had negligible variance as shown below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should uphold the existing stock controls and improve further.
attributes.effect: •  Minimal variations noted implied existence of adequate stock controls.

value: • We will enhance our stock controls by maintaining the shift-wise stock takes.
• The branch operations and stocks are well controlled and shift-wise stocks closely monitored, hence the minimal variations.

In the prior audit report dated  20th March 2025 stocks were as seen below:

  • Bread  stock -13.75 pieces
  • Wheat Bran  +8.61 kg, and
  • Polybags  +1,477 pieces,
  • All other raw materials had negligible variance.
• Effective controls noted, however, there is need for improvement to eliminate the variances further.

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings (a) Borrowed Bread:

  •  A spot check on the weights of bread borrowed by the branch (since the branch had no production due to ongoing roof repair) was done on 24th April 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted significant instances of non-compliance to the standard weights whereby there were above 50% underweight cases noted across all varieties as detailed below:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Findings (b) Own Production:

  •   A spot check on the weights of bread produced by the branch was done on 25th April 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted minor cases of non-compliance to the standard weights as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation:
• The branch should conduct spot checks to verify and communicate any anomalies in bread-weight received/borrowed from other branches.  
  • The branch management to ensure adherence to the required dough/bread weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The presence of extreme cases of underweight loaves from borrowed stock implied lapses in verifying bread weight from inter-branch transfers and could attract major penalties if the bread is found in the market by the regulating authorities.
  • The presence of underweight loaves from own production implied lapses in adhering to the set bread-weight standards during the production process.

value:
• We will conduct random weight checks of borrowed bread and communicate to management for advice/direction.
  • We will monitor rotation of our own production to ensure no overcooling occurs due to skipping of varieties

• The bread was borrowed due to renovations, but we will be following up.
  • Random and frequent weights checks will be administered to make sure packed bread meets the correct weights required.

•  In the previous audit report dated 20th March 2025, 400g Bw, 200g Ml and 400g Ct varieties had significant underweight percentages, with 200g Ml showing the highest percentage of underweight at 49%.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of damages arising from production and market delivery/transit processes for the period 1st March to 23rd April 2025 to detect if the damage levels were within the set limits.
  • The findings were as follows:
    •  The production damage was 0.304% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% with a cost implication of KES 57,941.15
    • The market damage was 0.87% of the total sales , which was above the 0.5% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 201,783.71 as computed below.
attributes.recommendation: •  Enhance quality controls within the production and bread delivery processes to ensure there are minimal/acceptable levels of both production and market damages.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The production and market damage levels were above the set limits which implied unbudgeted losses/cost incurred due to excess damages.

value: • We have had issues with old baking tins for 400g Ctw which have led to increased production and market damages, however, we have made requisition for new tins to resolve/minimize the damages at the branch.

• High production damage was due to worn-out 400ct tins but replacement is in the process.
  • High market damages was due to  expiries from the supermarkets and the sales rep was notified to follow up on bread rotation in the outlets.
• During the prior audit dated 20th March 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.33% of the production and market damages stood at 0.95% of the total sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing charts and mixing chart summaries for the period 1st March to 23rd April 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • The following were noted:
    • The average yield was 191.54 loaves per bag but the system recorded a yield of 190.11 despite having loaves and bags whose yield was 191.55.
    • Average production was 101.63 bags equivalent to 83% of the set target of 122 bags for both Unit 1 & 2.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • No cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to follow up on yield computation error in the system.
attributes.effect:
• 83% production target achievement implied that the branch capacity was not fully utilized .
  •  The set yield and quality standards were achieved for production, however, the system’s recorded/computed yield was erroneous.

value:
• We produce based on market demand; therefore we could not attain 100% of the production target.
  • We will follow up on system yield.

• Low percentage of production targets was due to low branch sales whereby production was done as per the orders.
  • We will follow up on system yield.

·       During the prior audit, the following were noted :

  • Average yield 191.50
  • Average production 100.81 bags.
  • Utto ratio: 1:1

attributes.title: Crates Verification
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A review of the crate balances at the branch was done on 25th April 2025 to establish and assess the existence and effectiveness of crate stock movement controls at the branch.
  • We observed that crates had nil variance compared with book records, however, the route balances for Garissa, Kibichoi, S/Markets and Town routes were high as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should uphold the existing controls on crates movement and work towards minimizing crate balances in some routes.
attributes.effect: • The crates’ movement was well controlled, however, there was need to minimize crate balances in some routes.

value:
• Consistent stock takes and daily crate reconciliations aids us to keep track of our crates’ movement. We will maintain.
  • Garissa route takes one extra day to deliver and return crates, therefore the balance is always cleared after one day.
  • The other routes have schools and supermarkets that always maintain balances.

• We will maintain the crates’ stock controls.
  • Garissa route takes one extra day to deliver and return crates, therefore the balance is always cleared after one day. The other routes have schools and supermarkets that always maintain balances.

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis of the debt balances as at C.O.B 25/04/2025 (Exclusive of Supermarkets) was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.
  •  We noted that the outstanding debt for customers and schools was high at KES 4,796,021 .
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to follow up on pending debt balances.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Follow up to be done on pending balances for clearance.

value: • We will follow up with sales representative.
• We will follow up with sales representative.
• In the previous audit dated 20th March 2025, the outstanding debt was KES 1,843,816.45.
• Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was done on the efficiency of criteria for labour allocation to the production section for the period 1st March to 23rd April 2025.
  • We noted that the average production efficiency was 4.32 bags per production worker which surpassed the set standard of 4.3.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to maintain optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The branch had optimal allocation of workers therefore implying controlled labour cost of production.

value: • We will encourage the production team to maintain the trend.
• The previous audit report dated 20th March 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.38 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 1st March to 23rd April 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 92.75 crates per packer, which was subpar compared to the set standard as demonstrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should work towards attaining optimal allocation of packers based  the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not achieve the set target which implied extra labour costs amounting to KES 30,096 for hiring 33 excess workers.

value: • We had 3 instances of slicer machine breakdowns on 12th /14th March and 07th April which led to low efficiency but we will follow up on allocation of packers.
• The previous audit report dated 20th March 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 80.19 crates per packer

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st April to 23rd April 2025.
  • All the route vehicles’ fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation: • Uphold the fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: • Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled implying efficient controls existed.

value: • During the previous audit dated 20th March 2025, overall, the fuel consumption across the fleet was in line with the established standard rates.
